title: 107_hr4141
content: The Act is titled the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. This section provides definitions for key terms used in the "Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Protection and Enhancement Act of 2002", including Corporation, Red Rock, Red Rock Map, and Secretary. SEC. 3. FINDINGS AND PURPOSES. The Congress finds Red Rock to be a significant natural resource that must be protected for future generations. The Southern Nevada Public Lands Management Act of 1998 aimed to enhance Red Rock. The Corporation owns land on Red Rock's eastern boundary and plans to develop a master-planned community, including 1,071 acres of high-ground lands intended for Red Rock. The Corporation owns 1,071 acres of high-ground lands at the eastern edge of Red Rock, intended for inclusion in a master-planned community. They have volunteered to forgo development of these lands and propose that the United States acquire them to preserve the view-shed of the western Las Vegas Valley. This Act aims to exchange these lands with the United States for preservation purposes. The Act aims to exchange high-ground lands owned by the Corporation with the United States to protect Red Rock, expand its boundaries, and fulfill the purposes of previous land management acts. SEC. 4. RED ROCK LAND EXCHANGE. The Red Rock Land Exchange involves the Corporation offering approximately 1,082 acres of nonfederal land to the United States. In return, the Secretary will convey approximately 998 acres of Federal lands to the Corporation and approximately 1,221 acres to Clark County, Nevada. The conveyances must be completed within 90 days of the offer. The Red Rock Map shows BLM lands for Clark County Park. Title to private and Federal property will be conveyed simultaneously. The Secretary will keep the map for public inspection. Conditions include hazardous materials removal and survey requirements for conveyance. The Corporation must remove hazardous materials on the property conveyed to the United States. A survey of the common boundary must be provided within 90 days. Lands transferred to Clark County must be held in perpetuity. The Secretary requires lands transferred to Clark County to be held in perpetuity for public park use or as part of a regional trail system. If the County tries to transfer or use the lands inconsistently, they will revert to the United States. SEC. 5. STATUS AND MANAGEMENT OF LANDS. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the lands depicted on the Red Rock Map as "Flood Control Detention Basin Lands" as part of Red Rock, excluding those used for the Corps of Engineers R-4 Detention Basin. Acquired lands will also be administered as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws. Upon enactment of this Act, the Secretary will administer the lands as part of Red Rock in accordance with relevant laws. New maps will be created to show the modified boundaries of Red Rock, available for review at designated Bureau of Land Management offices. Additionally, a conforming amendment will be made to include additional areas in the conservation area. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990 will be amended to include additional areas as part of the conservation area. The Red Rock Canyon National Conservation Area Establishment Act of 1990 will be amended to include additional areas as part of the conservation area. Section 6 outlines general provisions. The Secretary must review an appraisal and any difference in values must be reimbursed. The land exchange is subject to valid existing rights. Parties can agree to correct technical errors in the Red Rock Map. The Secretary will withdraw Federal lands acquired or owned by the United States under the Act from public land and mining laws, subject to valid existing rights. Parties can correct technical errors in the Red Rock Map. The House of Representatives passed the bill on October 1, 2002.
